newsitem.title: HUNGARY: BUDAPEST GRAINS FUTURES SURGE ON CHICAGO.
newsitem.headline: BUDAPEST GRAINS FUTURES SURGE ON CHICAGO.

text.p: Grains futures continued their week-longe surge on the Budapest Commodity Exchange (BCE) on Monday with all eyes on Chicago trends, traders said.
"The rise was certainly not due to domestic fundamentals, as those would not have affected old (1996) crop prices," said Janos Szolyka of Swap.
Untraded maize prices went higher by the daily allowed 400 forints for all but March and May 1998.
October and December milling wheat accounted for the lion's share of turnover with 785 contracts out of a meagre grains turnover of 918 contracts or 509.6 million forints.
The above two milling wheat maturities saw trade as their price was freed from the daily limit, Szolyka said.
"Nobody was prepared to sell at limit-up prices as they expect the rising trend to continue," he said.
October milling wheat rose 800 forints per tonne to 26,800 forints and December finished at 27,810, up 810.
Surging milling wheat prices triggered similar movements in other grains, resulting in identically high feed wheat prices for the August maturity at 24,500 forints.
"This was clearly hysteria as feed wheat just is not worth as much as milling wheat," Szolyka said. The only traded feed wheat maturity was December which rose 5,180 forints to 26,980.
Szolyka added that as yet unconfirmed market rumours of the European Union stopping grains exports could have also contributed to the general surge.
Feed barley went 2,200 forints higher for the only traded maturity, July.
